image.altText: Sally McManus holding a report, standing next to Professor Allan Fels.

props.synopsis: The former chair of the ACCC takes aim at electricity providers, banks, airlines, supermarkets, and other big businesses in his new report on price gouging and unfair pricing practices.

title.children: 'Misuse of corporate power': Price gouging report finds big businesses exploiting Australians

image.altText: Police cars parked in a driveway near a crime scene

props.synopsis: The man allegedly shot a 29-year-old Deception Bay woman inside a unit complex before calling triple-0.

title.children: Police charge 18yo with murder over shooting north of Brisbane

image.altText: King Charles waves to a crowd as Queen Camilla walks ahead.

props.synopsis: When Charles became king, he moved to expand the number of counsellors of state who could carry out his duties if he were to become seriously ill. The move may have foreshadowed this exact scenario, saving him from potentially awkward speculation about what role Prince Harry and Prince Andrew could play while he recovers.

title.children: How a quiet move by King Charles may have saved him — and Prince Harry — an awkward media circus

image.altText: A 70-year-old woman with shoulder length brown hair sitting down.

props.synopsis: Premier Steven Miles has flagged raising the prospect of opening children's court to the media with the Attorney-General after access was denied in relation to the alleged murder of Vyleen White.

title.children: Shopping centre stabbing prompts premier to call for better media access to children's court

image.altText: A drone shot of a new housing estate, with houses stretching as far as the eye can see

props.synopsis: There are two things the prime minister needs to get into his head about tax. One is that saying he won't make any further changes no longer works. The other is that negative gearing doesn't do much to get people into homes, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Is it time to stop rewarding landlords who can't make money?

image.altText: A profit chart on an tablet screen continues to increase

props.synopsis: The Queensland government made $1.9 billion in gambling taxes last year, but only spent 0.6 per cent on harm minimisation programs.

title.children: How much does the Queensland government profit from the gambling industry?

image.altText: Jennifer Crumbley is escorted out of court, wearing white jumper and black pants. Two police by her side.

props.synopsis: A Michigan jury convicts the mother of a teenager who fatally shot four classmates at a high school near Detroit of manslaughter.

title.children: US jury finds school shooter's mother guilty of manslaughter in groundbreaking trial

image.altText: Side photo of Queensland police car.

props.synopsis: A man and a woman have been taken into custody in connection with the death of a two-year old girl in North Mackay in 2022.

title.children: Man, woman arrested in Mackay as police investigate toddler death

image.altText: suicide inquest graphic

props.synopsis: It's been five years since an inquest laid bare the chaotic lives of children, including a 10-year-old girl, who took their own lives in outback Australia. Are kids any safer now?

title.children: 'I heard this terrible screaming': Five years on, has anything changed since 13 children and young people died by suicide?

image.altText: Phoebe is seen in a polaroid smiling with her tongue out, overlaid on top of an image of her Queenslander installation.

props.synopsis: Brisbane artist Phoebe Paradise turns the tension between Queenslander houses and their environment into works of gothic, sci-fi art.

title.children: Who gets to stay above the flood line in Brisbane? This question consumes Phoebe Paradise

image.altText: A close up of a person's hands, one holding an iPhone and one holding a small flip phone.

props.synopsis: With mobile phone use on the rise, some people are turning to simpler devices to help them cut down on their screen time.

title.children: Sick of doomscrolling and being 'constantly on call', these Australians switched to a 'dumbphone'

image.altText: Sparse traffic on Story Bridge in Brisbane city towards Kangaroo Point during COVID-19 lockdown

props.synopsis: The Greens pledge to push for trams to come back to Brisbane if they gain power at next month's council election, as the LNP prepares to announce more details about its Metro expansion plan.

title.children: Greens announce $10m light rail study in Brisbane election pitch as LNP flags Metro expansion

image.altText: RBA governor Michele Bullock holds her hand up while speaking at a press conference.

props.synopsis: In just half a sentence, the Reserve Bank board dashed the rate cut hopes of millions of mortgage borrowers. Does it risk condemning the Australian economy to recession as well?

title.children: Australian households are no longer driving demand and inflation, so why punish them with higher interest rates?

image.altText: Whale shark swimming by back of a boat

props.synopsis: The two men did not know whale sharks could be found in waters off Queensland's south-east coast until the inquisitive creature glided up next to their boat.

title.children: Sea sickness puts fishermen in path of rare whale shark off K'gari

image.altText: Jari Wise and Melissa Oates, undated photo

props.synopsis: It was a dramatic start to the long-awaited inquest into the death of young Tasmanian father Jari Wise, who was killed after a car driven by his former partner struck on a road at night.

title.children: 'I would rather be locked up': One witness arrested, another warned at inquest for man struck down by car driven by ex

image.altText: A picture of a sign that says 'Daisy Hill Conservation Park and Koala Centre' with trees and a road in the background.

props.synopsis: The state government purchases a large parcel of land that will be added to the Daisy Hill Conservation Park, which features mountain bike tracks, walking paths, picnic areas, horse riding trails, and a koala centre.

title.children: Major conservation park home to koalas near Brisbane to grow by 213 hectares

image.altText: Killer Mike holding three Grammys and smiling widely, wearing all black, standing in press room with pics of Grammys and logos

props.synopsis: Rapper Killer Mike has released a statement about what he says led to his arrest at the Grammys, after he had just won three awards.

title.children: Killer Mike says an 'over-zealous' security guard is what led to his Grammys arrest

image.altText: A man in a workshirt and large hat standing looking sombre in front of a paddock of cows.

props.synopsis: Farmer Daniel Perry's rates have gone up 66 per cent in three years and, as the value of his land increases, he expects an even bigger rates bill in 2024.

title.children: Queensland grazier says rural rates have risen so much, it's putting his family business at risk

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe at a press conference.

props.synopsis: The government appears to have reached a deal on its remaining industrial relations changes, as independent Lidia Thorpe says she "will be supporting" the move. Follow live.

title.children: 'Further protection for casuals': Labor looks to have the votes needed to pass workplace laws overhaul

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Industrial relations reforms appear to have numbers needed to pass
Greens attempt to suspend orders in both houses to debate support for Israel

image.altText: A woman at the train station in the evening checks her smartphone

props.synopsis: If you've ever found yourself replying to a 10pm email, or fielding a phone call from the boss during a Saturday afternoon barbecue, and wondered "should I be getting paid for this?", the answer is … maybe.

title.children: You might soon have the right to 'disconnect' from work. Here's what else may be on the way

image.altText: Two men wearing suits hold papers as they walk.

props.synopsis: Kristian White, 33, made a surprise appearance at court this morning, while other charges in relation to the tasering of Clare Nowland last year were withdrawn.

title.children: Court hears police officer will plead not guilty to tasering manslaughter of 95yo with dementia

image.altText: Man with two women in bikinis

props.synopsis: Sir Bruce Small had a bold plan to revive tourism on the Gold Coast. All he needed was a bevy of beautiful women and a captive audience in cold southern states.

title.children: 'We were on the front page of every paper': How a mayor and a few girls in bikinis sold brand Gold Coast

image.altText: Two dancer embrace holding eucalyptus leaves

props.synopsis: The commission also that found that if governments continue to put money towards programs that don't align with what the community is saying will work, then governments will continue to allocate public money ineffectively.

title.children: Commission's first review reveals 'tokenistic' Closing the Gap strategies falling short

image.altText: Prince Harry shows no emotion as he leaves the High Court in London.

props.synopsis: Prince Harry arrives in London and spends about 45 minutes at his father's royal residence, Clarence House, on Tuesday as King Charles III is pictured for the first time since his cancer diagnosis was made public.

title.children: Harry's flying 45-minute visit after King Charles III's cancer diagnosis

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market opened higher this morning, led by miners after a two-day losing streak. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens higher led by miners, NAB appoints new CEO

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 'Business price setting has contributed significantly to inflation', Fels says
Rising prices often driven by corporate greed and exploiting market power
Professor Allan Fels to release findings of price gouging inquiry

image.altText: Julalikari Corporation property in Tennant Creek

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal corporation in the remote Northern Territory town of Tennant Creek is facing allegations it misappropriated hundreds of thousands of dollars in public funding.

title.children: One of Australia's largest Indigenous corporations is being investigated. Here's why

image.altText: A person in an orange jumper stands beside a person in a yellow jumper while pointing at a helicopter.

props.synopsis: Army veterans and engineers who once worked on Australia's now grounded fleet of Taipan helicopters are volunteering to rebuild the aircraft so they can be sent to Ukraine rather than be buried in an expensive disposal process.

title.children: Last-ditch offer to divert Taipan helicopters from being scrapped to help Ukraine

image.altText: A panel is missing from the side of an aircraft between two rows of passenger seats.

props.synopsis: The findings are the result of an initial report by a US safety board investigating the incident.

title.children: A door panel that flew off a Boeing  jet mid-flight appeared to be missing four key bolts

image.altText: Three young women wearing bikinis smile. A graphic of sunscreen, sunglasses and a juice are in front of them.

props.synopsis: Hearing "slip, slop, slap" and "no hat, no play" in childhood hasn't kept today's teens and young adults out of the sun. But there is hope social media campaigns can change attitudes about tanning.

title.children: They know it's harmful but young Australians still think it's cool to be tanned
